nexttext:
where $s$ indicates the concentration of galactose outside the cell, $C$ is the maximal transport rate, proportional to the amount of membrane transporters like Gal2p, and $K_M$ is the Michaelis constant of the facilitated diffusion reaction \cite{Barnett1997} (its value taken from \cite{Kasahara11022000}). 

For the WT strain the differential equations for the protein concentrations are:

prevtext:
where $s$ indicates the concentration of galactose outside the cell, $C$ is the maximal transport rate, proportional to the amount of membrane transporters like Gal2p, and $K_M$ is the Michaelis constant of the facilitated diffusion reaction \cite{Barnett1997} (its value taken from \cite{Kasahara11022000}). 

For the WT strain the differential equations for the protein concentrations are:

\noindent where $S$ is the external galactose, $G=G1$ is the amount of metabolic enzyme, and $\rho$ is the ratio between the cost of producing the enzyme and the maximum growth rate benefit achieved by burning galactose. 

In a stochastic nutrient information processing setting \cite{Bialek2012}, the mean growth rate can be defined as:

\noindent where $P(S)$  represents probability of the cell sensing an amount of galactose $S$, and $P(G|S)$ the probability of G responding to S. The mutual information that flows between the external galactose concentration ($S$) and the relative concentration of Gal1p ($G$) is:
prevtext:
\noindent where $S$ is the external galactose, $G=G1$ is the amount of metabolic enzyme, and $\rho$ is the ratio between the cost of producing the enzyme and the maximum growth rate benefit achieved by burning galactose. 

In a stochastic nutrient information processing setting \cite{Bialek2012}, the mean growth rate can be defined as:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\langle\tilde{r}\rangle=\int dSP(S)\int dGP(G|S)\tilde{r}(G|S)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: \noindent where $P(S)$  represents probability of the cell sensing an amount of galactose $S$, and $P(G|S)$ the probability of G responding to S. The mutual information that flows between the external galactose concentration ($S$) and the relative concentration of Gal1p ($G$) is:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="I(G,S)=\int dGdSP(G,S)\log\frac{P(G,S)}{P(G)P(S)}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $s$ is the amount of external galactose, $s_{in}$ is the amount of nutrients inside the cell, $s_a$  quantifies the amount of sugar  in the cell available for growing. The total amount of galactose available in the cell at the steady state is given by the amount of sugar it gets from the environment minus the amount of sugar that is consumed by $g$.

Solving eq. (\ref{sys}) for $s_a = f(s_{in})$ one can directly express the growth rate as a function of the external galacotse concentration $s$:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8X.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=C\frac{s}{s+K_{M}}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>s</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>M</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8Xa.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle s_{a}" display="inline"><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8Xa.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=s_{in}-\xi g\frac{s_{a}}{s_{a}+K}=C\frac{s}{s+K_{M}}-\xi g\frac{%
s_{a}}{s_{a}+K}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>s</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>M</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8Xb.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle r(s_{a},g)" display="inline"><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8Xb.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\xi g\frac{s_{a}}{s_{a}+K}-\mu g" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>g</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $s$ is the amount of external galactose, $s_{in}$ is the amount of nutrients inside the cell, $s_a$  quantifies the amount of sugar  in the cell available for growing. The total amount of galactose available in the cell at the steady state is given by the amount of sugar it gets from the environment minus the amount of sugar that is consumed by $g$.

Solving eq. (\ref{sys}) for $s_a = f(s_{in})$ one can directly express the growth rate as a function of the external galacotse concentration $s$:

nexttext: we get the rescaled growth rate law in units of $\xi K$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10X.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{s_{in}}{2K}\rightarrow S" display="inline"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>s</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>→</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10Xa.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\frac{g}{2K}\rightarrow G" display="inline"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>g</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>→</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where now the only parameter is $\rho = \frac{ \mu }{\xi}$, which represents the ratio between the cost of making the enzyme and the growth rate advantage from burning galactose.

Since the overall growth rate of the cell must also take into account the contribution other mechanisms that contribute to growth, $R_{ext}$, which we consider to be constant. We set $R_{ext} = 0.0050$ to account for the doubling time shift from 110 mins. in raffinose to 120 mins. in galactose \cite{Ferry2010} and $K = 15$ to account for the G1 fold change data.

The mean growth rate is defined as:
prevtext: we get the rescaled growth rate law in units of $\xi K$:

nexttext:
where $P(S)$  represents how the input signal fluctuates, or in other 
words, what is the probability distribution such that the cell gets $s$ 
level of galactose. 

Based on an idea from Bialek \cite{Bialek2012}, we can ask: how precisely must $G$ track $S$ in order to grow at a certain rate, $ \langle r \rangle$? This optimization problem can be solved using the Lagrange multipliers to define a function:
prevtext:
where now the only parameter is $\rho = \frac{ \mu }{\xi}$, which represents the ratio between the cost of making the enzyme and the growth rate advantage from burning galactose.

Since the overall growth rate of the cell must also take into account the contribution other mechanisms that contribute to growth, $R_{ext}$, which we consider to be constant. We set $R_{ext} = 0.0050$ to account for the doubling time shift from 110 mins. in raffinose to 120 mins. in galactose \cite{Ferry2010} and $K = 15$ to account for the G1 fold change data.

The mean growth rate is defined as:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\langle\tilde{r}\rangle=\int dSP(S)\int dGP(G|S)\tilde{r}(G|S)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent where $\lambda$ and $\mu(S)$ are the Lagrange multipliers. To get the optimal read out system we need to minimize it with respect to $P(G|S)$. For a given $\langle r \rangle$, this defines the optimal read out system $P(G|S)$ such that the growth rate is maximized. Or rather for given $I(g,s)$ it is possible to define the maximum growth rate accessible $r_{opt}$.

We can use this tool to compare models where the dilution rate $\gamma$ is considered constant and where it changes dynamically with the growth rate. Changing the number of molecules in the cell, i.e., the amount of intrinsic noise of the network, we want to see how these two models perform in terms of growth rate. Indeed, we can use the parameter $N$ as a proxy for the intrinsic noise of the network: when $N$ is small the noise is high and vice-versa.

What we expect is that the negative feed back of G1 on its own expression keeps the noise low also when the initial number of molecules in the cell is small. When $\gamma$ is constant (nGFB) the noise in the expression of G1 is large when $N$ is low and decreases for increasing $N$. Note that both models tend to the optimal at the high limit of $N$.  Our aim is to compute how the gal network reads out the environment and compare it with the optimal case.
prevtext:
where $P(S)$  represents how the input signal fluctuates, or in other 
words, what is the probability distribution such that the cell gets $s$ 
level of galactose. 

Based on an idea from Bialek \cite{Bialek2012}, we can ask: how precisely must $G$ track $S$ in order to grow at a certain rate, $ \langle r \rangle$? This optimization problem can be solved using the Lagrange multipliers to define a function:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mathcal{F}[P(G|S)]=I(G,S)-\lambda\langle r\rangle-\int\mu(S)dS\int dGP(G|S)" display="block"><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℱ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>λ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
